item.title: Pain
item.description: a complex, and subjective sensory and emotional experience that is associated with actual or potential tissue damage it is a signal in our nervous systems that something is wrong

item.title: Perception of Pain
item.description: ![[Perception#Definition]] [[Tolerance of Pain]]

item.title: HIV
item.description: HIV Human Immunodeficiency Virus it attacks the immune system if left untreated, it can progress to AIDS targets white blood cells

item.title: Abiogenesis
item.description: the natural process by which life arises from non-living matter, such as simple organic compounds. It is also known as the origin of life, and it is one of the major unsolved problems in biology

item.title: LUCA
item.description: hypothetical organism that is the most recent common ancestor of all living organisms on Earth. It is estimated to have lived about 3.

item.title: Heredity
item.description: Heredity, also called inheritance or biological inheritance, is the passing on of genetic material from parent to offspring The study of heredity in biology is called genetics

item.title: Late Adulthood
item.description: Physical Development Brain shrinks; 5-10% loss in mass Brain volume decreases (up to 15%) Immune System Decline Low level of protein linked to decrease in T cells

item.title: Middle Adulthood
item.description: Change in physical appearance skin begins to wrinkle and sag because of a loss of fat and collagen in underlying tissues hair thins and greys pigmentation Height and weight

item.title: Perinatal Period
item.description: During or around birth

item.title: Phases of Prenatal Development
Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love
item.description: Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love Intimacy Passion Commitment Non-love Liking/friendship ✔ Infatuated love ✔ Empty love ✔ Romantic love ✔ ✔ Companionate love ✔ ✔ Fatuous love ✔ ✔ Consummate love ✔ ✔ ✔

item.title: Senescence
item.description: Senescence / Biological aging gradual deterioration of functioning can refer to aging of either cell whole organism biological aging vs chronological aging factors contributing towards aging lifestyle stress diet sleep drugs exercise environment UV ray exposure quality of life genes telomere length disorders see also [[negative senescence]]

item.title: Theories of Aging
item.description: [[Midlife Crisis| <- midlife crisis]] Theories of [[Senescence|Aging]] flowchart A(Theories of Aging)--B(Programmed Theories)--D(Programmed Longevity) A--C(Error Theories)--M(Wear and Tear) B--E(Endocrine) Why would aging be programmed into our genes?
Oestrogen - Ovulation thinning of mucus thickening of lining Progesterone - Menstrual Cycle thickening of mucus thinning of lining FSH - pituitary gland -

item.title: Assessing of newborns
item.description: APGAR Scale done at one and five minutes after A - Appearance P - Pulse G - Reflexes A - Activity

item.title: Birth Complications
item.description: Low birth weight - below 5.5 pounds - very low weight - extremely low weight - below 2.5 preterm infants small for date (aka small for gestational age)

item.title: Stages of birth
item.description: The Birth Process occurs in three stages First Stage Uterine contractions cause the woman’s cervix to stretch and open DILATE the cervix to an opening of ~10cm so baby can move from uterus to birth canal

item.title: Types of Birth
item.description: Natural aims to decrease pain by decreasing fear through education about childbirth and breathing techniques are used 1. Natural Vaginal

item.title: Genes in relation to lifespan development
item.description: Sex Linked vs Sex Limited Genes Chromosomal vs Gene Linked Down Kleinfelter Fragile X Turner Syndrome XYY [!

item.title: Telomere
item.description: Region of DNA, at the end of chromosomes Becomes shorter every time a cell divides Helps ensure ends of chromosome don’t get frayed
